block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow: Teleplays into film; at 2, Delbert Mann's ''Marty'' (1955); at 4, Sidney Lumet's ''12 Angry Men'' (1957). Sunday at 2: directed by Alfred Hitchcock; at 2, ''Rear Window'' (1954); at 4:30, ''The Wrong Man'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday night at 6:30, Jacques Demy's ''Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' (1964). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow: Teleplays into film; at 2, Delbert Mann's ''Marty'' (1955); at 4, Sidney Lumet's ''12 Angry Men'' (1957). Sunday at 2: directed by Alfred Hitchcock; at 2, ''Rear Window'' (1954); at 4:30, ''The Wrong Man'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday night at 6:30, Jacques Demy's ''Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' (1964). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8, with Bobby Sanabria y Quinteto Ache, through Aug. 25. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Sunday from 2 to 3:30 p.m, a walking tour of important Jewish sites in Manhattan, beginning at the museum. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

STATEN ISLAND INSTITUTE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Cultural museum and library with artistic, scientific and environmental collections. ''Famous People From Staten Island,'' including photographs, vintage periodicals, posters and memorabilia. ''In the Eye of the Beholder: Portraits From the Permanent Collection,'' including works that look at the evolution of portraiture in a variety of different media. ''Jacques Reich: Portraits.'' All through Sept. 4. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $2.50; students, children and the elderly, $1.50; free for members. Information: (718) 727-1135.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Through Sept. 16, butterfly and hummingbird trails open for tours, with related crafts and other activities on weekends. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open, with guided tours available. ''100 Flowers,'' botanical series by Harold Feinstein. Through August 20. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The Exotic Courtyard Garden is open through Sept. 24. Through mid-September, the summer gardens are in bloom, with the day lily collections in peak bloom through mid-August. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Sundays in August, special photography events, displays and contests for visitors wishing to bring their cameras, including this weekend at 11 a.m., a discussion on using equipment to its best advantage, followed by a field trip to demonstrate. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. ''Welcome,'' works by 11 artists exploring ideas of home and the relationship between people and nature; through Aug. 20. Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.
Cruises

ADIRONDACK, leaving from Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, 23rd Street on the Hudson River. An 80-foot schooner that goes on two-hour sails daily (around New York Harbor) at 10:30 a.m., 1, 3:30, 6 and 9 p.m. Tickets: weekdays, $30 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $40, and includes drinks; weekends, $35 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail. which is $45, including drinks. Information: (800) 701-7245.

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Clinton. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.

PIONEER, the historic schooner, sails from the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, South and Fulton Streets, for a two-hour cruise. Sunset cruises Tuesdays through Sundays at 7 p.m.; also 9:30 p.m. sails Tuesdays through Saturdays; additional sails Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 4 p.m. Tickets: sunset cruises $25; other sails $20, $15 for students and the elderly and $12 for children 12 and under.
EVENTS

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a rotating trio of percussionists: Mary Knyshok, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

''ROMEO AND JULIET,'' Harlem School of the Arts, Courtyard Theater, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street. A hip-hop version of Shakespeare's work performed outdoors by the Classical Theater of Harlem. Today through Sunday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 539-8828.

ANNUAL HARLEM WEEK 2000 BLACK FILM FESTIVAL, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building, 163 West 125th Street. Through Aug. 13. Today's features include ''Fields of Endless Day'' (1978), 2:55 p.m.; ''Ladies of Jazz and Blues'' (1995), 6:30 p.m. Tomorrow: ''Dorothy Dandridge: The Diva's Lost Films'' (2000), 1 and 4:30 p.m. and ''Black's in Blue Comedy: Tribute to Redd Foxx'' (1999), 6:30 p.m.; Sunday: ''Slave Trade in the World Today'' (1964), 1 p.m. and ''Malcolm X: Make it Plan'' (1994), 6 p.m. Admission, $5; $4 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 749-5298.

''A DAY AT THE BEACH: SCUBA OBSERVATION,'' Coney Island Beach, Boardwalk and West Eighth Street. Participants will examine lobsters, rock and horseshoe crabs, sea urchins and other sea life retrieved by scuba divers at a free event sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers and the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. Sunday, 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. Information: 1 (888) 697-2757.
ECUADOREAN INDEPENDENCE DAY FESTIVAL, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Ecuadorean Civic Committee of New York and the Queens Council on the Arts.

''BROOKLYN BRIDGE AND BARGEMUSIC,'' a walk through Lower Manhattan with a stroll across the bridge and a stop in Brooklyn for a concert at Bargemusic. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Fee, $55. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.

''SOARING HEIGHTS: THE CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE,'' an architectural tour of the neo-Gothic cathedral. Sunday at 2 p.m. Fee, $30. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.
RECREATION

MANHATTAN HALF-MARATHON, Central Park. A 13-mile run, beginning tomorrow at 7:30 a.m., behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art, on the East Park Drive and 85th Street. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race-day registration, $22, $15 for club members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.

''GREATER HARLEM-CON EDISON HISTORIC BIKE TOUR,'' a 12-mile tour in upper Manhattan, beginning at the Grant Memorial, Riverside Drive and West 122nd Street. Sunday at 10 a.m. Registration, $15; $5 for ages 6 to 12. Proceeds benefit the Harlem Y.M.C.A. and the Harlem Week Community College Fund. Information: (212) 410-0030, extension 246.
ON THE STREET
GREENWICH VILLAGE FAIR, West Fourth Street from LaGuardia Place to Avenue of the Americas. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Children's Aid Society.
HOLY APOSTLES STREET FAIR, 23rd Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Chelsea. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen.
CARIBBEAN FESTIVAL, Amsterdam Avenue from 190th to 193rd Streets, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
FESTIVAL OF THE AMERICAS, Avenue of the Americas from 42nd to 57th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Avenue of the Americas Association.

ROCKAWAY BOARDWALK ARTS AND CRAFTS FAIR, from 113th to 115th Streets, Queens. Every Saturday and Sunday through Labor Day, 11 a.m. to dusk. Sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation.
JAMAICA AVENUE (JAMS) FESTIVAL, Jamaica Avenue from Parsons Boulevard to 169th Street, Queens. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by Jamaica Arts and Music.
WALKING TOURS

YANKEE STADIUM, the Bronx. An insider's tour of the baseball arena, including Monument Park and the dugout. Meets many Fridays and Saturdays at noon at the press gate when the team is away. Fee, $8; $4 for children 14 and younger and the elderly. Information: (718) 579-4531.

''SOUTH STREET SEAPORT/DUTCH ORIGINS OF NEW YORK,'' from South Ferry to the South Street Seaport. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Fee, $11. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 629-1886.

''BEHIND THE FENCES WALKING TOURS,'' Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A free tour of the park's newly restored ravine, filled with trees, birds and a reflecting pool that is home to turtles, dragonflies and numerous varieties of fish. Every Saturday at 3 p.m. and every Sunday at 1 and 3 p.m through November. Sponsored by the Prospect Park Alliance and the Urban Park Rangers. Information: (718) 965-6988.

''AFFLUENT ENCLAVE,'' Manhattan, covers the Beekman Place-Sutton Place area with stops at the former residences of Irving Berlin, Greta Garbo and Rex Harrison. Meets tomorrow at 12:30 p.m. on the northwest corner of 52nd Street and First Avenue. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

PARK SLOPE, Brooklyn, covers the architecture and history of this landmark district. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the southwest corner of Flatbush Avenue and Plaza Street West. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''AYN RAND'S NEW YORK.'' Two tours exploring the architecture that influenced Rand and sites associated with her. ''Skyscrapers of 'The Fountainhead' '' meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. inside Bowling Green Park. ''Cerf's Up,'' with a focus on architecture and the media, meets Sunday at 11 a.m. on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 58th Street. Fee for each tour: $15. Information: (201) 433-0946.

''GOTHAM CITY GHOST TOUR,'' Greenwich Village. Covers historic and infamous spots, including Edgar Allan Poe's home and the burial ground at Washington Square. Tomorrow at 5 p.m. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Fee, $12. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 465-3331.

''THE HIDDEN CHARMS OF CHELSEA: SEMINARY, BROWNSTONES AND SHOCKING INHABITANTS'' traces development of the area from its beginnings as Clement Clarke Moore's 100-acre farm. Meets tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the General Theological Seminary, Ninth Avenue and 20th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''THE JACK FINNEY 'TIME AND AGAIN' TOUR,'' Midtown Manhattan, retraces the steps of the time traveler Simon Morley from the Dakota Apartments to Central Park. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. on the northwest corner of Central Park West and 72nd Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $45. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY, Brooklyn, covers the history and architecture of the ''City of the Dead,'' as well as the noted people buried there, including Louis C. Tiffany. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the entrance at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Sunset Park. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''EDGAR ALLAN POE AND HIS GHOSTLY FRIENDS,'' Greenwich Village and the East Village. Explore the neighborhoods and learn about the ghosts of Edgar Allan Poe, Peter Stuyvesant and others. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. outside the Second Avenue Deli, 156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil's New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''A FOREST IN THE CITY,'' Central Park. Stops at the tulip tree, the Great Hill and the Harlem Meer. Meets Sunday at 1:45 p.m. at the Boy's Gate, Central Park West at 100th Street. Sponsored by the Friends of the Parks. Donation, $1.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. Stops at several cultural institutions, and this weekend wraps in the site of an outdoor baptism. Meets on Sundays at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
